Delayed and canceled flights, untimely airport power outages, lost bags—the list is endless and frequently updated. My luck with places to stay isn’t much better (I’m talking to you, flooded Italian Airbnb). That is, until I checked into The Siren hotel in Detroit.ASH NYC, a very cool design and development firm based in Brooklyn, designed the hotel, and it looks like it’s straight out of a Wes Anderson film in the least kitschy way possible. The lobby is a dreamy space filled with opulent velvet furniture, stacks of vintage Holiday magazines, and a color palette I need to apply to my own life (olive green, burnt orange, deep navy blue). The rooms are no-frills—and affordable, with rates starting at around $100 a night—but that doesn’t make The Siren feel any less special.Come for the cocktails, stay for the vibes.
Photo by Christian HarderPlus, Candy Bar, the intimate cocktail lounge on the lobby level from local chef Kate Williams, is a perfect place for a nightcap. The last time I was at The Siren, I grabbed a bubbly cocktail and cozied up in a pink velvet booth in the corner before heading back up to my room, feeling ready to take on yet another delayed flight and lost bag.Go there: The SirenExplore Bon AppétitHighly RecommendHotelsDetroitRead MorerestaurantsWhy I'll Be Spending My Entire D.C.
